title: Centaur & which Sans serif?
content:
Hi  
Im doing a book on art and museums, and I was thinking of using Centaur...can you please suggest a sans serif font that is a good combination with Centaur?  
Also, would you recommend any other serif/sans serif font combinations which are historically relevant to art and museums?  
Any feedback would be much appreciated.  
...Thank you!
author: EyeLoveDesign

comments.content: Centaur, in its digital incarnation, is a weak typeface. You could try [Adobe Jenson](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018095246/http:/store4.adobe.com/cfusion/store/html/index.cfm?store=OLS-US&event=displayFontPackage&code=1716), based on the same sources.

Hi Neha,

you might like [Legacy](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018095246/http:/www.fonts.com/FontPackages/SuperFamilies/11-01-2004.htm). Like Centaur, it is a revival of the work of [Nicolas Jenson](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018095246/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Nicolas%20Jenson) – and it has a sans companion!  
Furthermore, I can imagine [Today Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018095246/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/today-sans/) to work quite well.

Related thread: [Sans Companion for Bembo Book](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018095246/http:/typophile.com/node/31046)  
F

@Manlio: digital Monotype Centaur is weak, but my accurate digital reconstruction, [Museum](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018095246/http:/www.levien.com/type/myfonts/museum.html), is much stronger. Unfortunately, quite incomplete, so, while it might be usable for some display work, it's nowhere near ready for being a text face for a book.
@raph: I was aware of it and I hope you will complete it soon.

Maybe Syntax, or Today Sans.

hhp

Shinntype's [Figgins Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018095246/http:/www.shinntype.com/figgins.html) has a small x-height and large contrast between cap and lower case stem widths.

You could use it with an oldstyle like Centaur or Bembo, or with [Scotch Modern](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018095246/http:/www.shinntype.com/scotch.html), which it was designed to partner.
